Row.Text: Church of Madoka

The Church of Madoka is a religion which teaches the existence of an omniscient and omnipresent Magical Girl named Madoka Kaname. There are no records indicating that such a person was ever born in this world. Though its primary constituents are Magical Girls, many young women without the potential for magic -- and even many men -- are also known to be active members.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The name of Madoka was first spoken by the prophet Homura Akemi. According to Akemi's gospel, before the advent of Madoka, Magical Girls lived in an alternate universe in which they became murderous monsters known as Witches once their Soul Gem became fully tainted. It was only through the power of Madoka's selfless wish that they can now live a happier existence. No further evidence has been uncovered to affirm the existence of such a girl. Yet, thousands of Magical Girls have accepted Akemi's gospel and feel an unspeakable gratitude towards Madoka.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Madoka Kaname is often compared to Jesus Christ due to certain parallels between their stories. According to the Gospel of Akemi, Madoka's wish caused her to absorb all of the curses from every Magical Girl in the past, present, and future, much like the death of Jesus forgave all humans of sin. It has also been noted that the date of Madoka's wish and her deification seems to have been on Good Friday -- coinciding with the date of Jesus's crucifixion.
Cult of Homura

The Cult of Homura is a newer religion which was created seemingly as a rejection of the Church of Madoka. Its tenets teach of another omniscient and omnipresent Magical Girl by the name of Homura Akemi, formerly known as the Great Prophet of the Church of Madoka, who usurped the power of Madoka Kaname and took her place as the deity of the universe. Notably, the adherents to this faith admit to Homura Akemi being a devil rather than a god, and make no attempts to argue against the viewpoint that she is evil. Though arguments between the supporters of Madoka and the supporters of Homura are numerous, they almost never turn into the empassioned, insulting arguments typical of other religious debates. This is perhaps due to the fact that the followers of both religions consider both deities to be lovers, in a ritual known as "Shipping," often performed with a ceremonial headpiece commonly known as "Yuri Goggles."

Yuriji

A Yuriji, literally "Lily Temple" in Japanese, is a temple of worship typically associated with the Church of Madoka and the Cult of Homura. Men are forbidden from entry. Aside from worship and gospel, Yurijis are also known as one of the only two acceptable places to conduct the "Luminous Ceremony." (The other is in the middle of a grassy field.)
Can only be built in cities following a religion with the Yurijis belief. Construct this building by purchasing it with [ICON_PEACE] Faith.
